title: FBC Melgar
text:
Foot Ball Club Melgar, known simply as FBC Melgar or Melgar, is a <a href="Peru">Peru</a>vian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> club based in <a href="Arequipa">Arequipa</a>, <a href="Peru">Peru</a>. It is one of Peru's oldest football teams, founded on 25 March 1915 by a group of football enthusiasts from Arequipa.
The team first participated in the <a href="Peruvian%20Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Peruvian football league</a> in 1919 in <a href="Lima">Lima</a> and later was invited to the first true National football league, the <a href="Torneo%20Descentralizado">Torneo Descentralizado</a>, in <a href="1966%20Torneo%20Descentralizado">1966</a>, when four teams from the provinces were invited to join the league. Joining them were <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Grau">Atlético Grau</a> from <a href="Piura">Piura</a>, <a href="Octavio%20Espinoza">Club Octavio Espinoza</a> from <a href="Ica%2C%20Peru">Ica</a> and <a href="Alfonso%20Ugarte%20de%20Chicl%C3%ADn">Alfonso Ugarte (Ch)</a> from <a href="Trujillo%2C%20Peru">Trujillo</a>. Previously, only teams from Lima and Callao had been allowed to compete for the national championship. Due to a low finish the first year, Melgar was dropped from the league after the first year. After winning the <a href="Copa%20Per%C3%BA">Copa Perú</a> they returned to the First Division where they have remained to this day. Melgar won the Torneo Descentralizado for the first time in <a href="1981%20Torneo%20Descentralizado">1981</a>. In the <a href="1983%20Torneo%20Descentralizado">1983 season</a> the club finished first in the First Stage and at the end the top six teams played a play-off tournament to determine the year's champion, which Melgar finished in second.
FBC Melgar plays its home games at the <a href="Estadio%20Melgar">Estadio Mariano Melgar</a>, but since the <a href="Estadio%20Monumental%20Virgen%20de%20Chapi">Estadio de la UNSA</a> was built in 1990 with a capacity of 40,000, it has used both.
History.
The club won nine cups in the departament of <a href="Arequipa">Arequipa</a>, and won the <a href="Copa%20Per%C3%BA">Copa Perú</a> in 1971. This championship allowed them to return to the First Division Campeonato Descentralizado where they currently remain.
Melgar won the <a href="1981%20Torneo%20Descentralizado">National Championship in 1981</a>, and Melgar was the <a href="1983%20Torneo%20Descentralizado">runner-up of the national championship in 1983</a>. In both these years this qualified them to play in the <a href="Copa%20Libertadores">Copa Libertadores</a>.
In 2014, <a href="Juan%20Reynoso%20Guzm%C3%A1n">Juan Reynoso</a>, who come from <a href="M%C3%A9xico">México</a>, was appointed as the new manager. He signed players like <a href="Piero%20Alva">Piero Alva</a>, <a href="Nelinho%20Quina">Nelinho Quina</a>, <a href="Minzum%20Quina">Minzum Quina</a>, <a href="Luis%20Alberto%20Hern%C3%A1ndez">Luis Hernández</a>, <a href="Alejandro%20Hohberg">Alejandro Hohberg</a>, <a href="Lampros%20Kontogiannis">Lampros Kontogiannis</a> and <a href="Edgar%20Villamar%C3%ADn">Edgar Villamarín</a> to make an impressive campaign where Melgar was the best team during the whole season finishing 1st in the accumulated table, but due to some bad results in the final matches and the poor organization of the tournament they weren't able to dispute the Play-off for the championship and only qualified for the <a href="Copa%20Sudamericana">Copa Sudamericana</a>.
In 2015, year of Melgar's centenary, and still with Reynoso as the manager, the team signed important players like <a href="Ra%C3%BAl%20Ruid%C3%ADaz">Raúl Ruidíaz</a>, <a href="Carlos%20Ascues">Carlos Ascues</a>, <a href="Johnnier%20Monta%C3%B1o">Johnnier Montaño</a>, <a href="Rainer%20Torres">Rainer Torres</a> and <a href="Daniel%20Ferreyra">Daniel Ferreyra</a> to make an impressive team and fight for the title.
This year, Melgar won the national championship, besting <a href="Sporting%20Cristal">Sporting Cristal</a> with a score in the final minute by <a href="Bernardo%20Cuesta">Bernardo Cuesta</a>.
Rivalries.
FBC Melgar has had a long-standing rivalry with <a href="Cienciano">Cienciano</a>, <a href="Sportivo%20Hurac%C3%A1n">Sportivo Huracán</a>, <a href="FBC%20Aurora">Aurora</a> and <a href="FBC%20Pi%C3%A9rola">Piérola</a>.
